bibl.title: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Ciro Hurtado to H. B. Richardson, August 23, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302020]

div1.p: Hurtado explains the basis for his diagnosis of yellow fever in the patient who died in Colima, Mexico, and asks that reports from the liver examination be provided to him.

div1.head: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Ciro Hurtado to H. B. Richardson, August 23, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302020]
div1.opener:
Translated from the Spanish.
9-5-23
HRM
DR. CIRO HURTADO
LIBERTAD 80
COLIMA, COL. MEXICO
DUPLICATE
August 23, 1923.
Mr. H. B. Richardson
Inspector General of the Sixth Zone.
My dear Sir:
div1.p:
In reply to your letter of the 21st instant which was duly
received, I take pleasure in communicating to you, as I have already done
verbally, that on that day I was called to give medical assistance at the
house located on Belizario Dominguez Calle opposite number 449. There
and at three o'clock in the afternoon I found a patient whose name is
Luis V. Corona in a state of agony. His pulse not perceptible in the
radial, his sweaty, wasted and pained features indicated the severity of
his condition. I noted that his abdomen was only slightly tympanized.
The patient had constant vomitings, which, according to what I was told,
were at first yellowish in color, later greenish, and when I saw them,
dark bloody color. I was shown some intestinal evacuations of dark bloody
color. On the following day a person called at my office for the death
certificate and he told me that the above mentioned Corona had died at
6:30 P.M. of the same day in which I had seen him, that is, three hours
after my only visit. On asking the person who called for the death certi-
ficate whether or not the cadaver had turned yellowish, he replied that it
had turned completely yellow.

Information given to me by the family of the patient on the day
of my visit showed that he became very much worse after the injection of
arsenas quinine administered on the 20th, the day before his death.
-2-
I was also told that he drank heavily and that during the five days of
his sickness the fever had been continuous and that he had suffered from
frequent but not periodical chills.

With this data I diagnosed the case as suspected yellow fever.
Please note that I say only suspected.

closer.seg:
P.S. As the time was very short, I gave you and Dr. Galindo a verbal
report of the case. I am glad that you were collecting part of the liver,
to confirm our diagnosis. I am writing to ask you to please let me know
the result of the liver examination when you receive the report from Mexico.
Yours truly,
(Signed)Ciro Hurtado.
